title: Directs the commissioner of transportation to use a salt substitute to deice certain highways bordering the Kensico and Croton watershed
summary: Directs the commissioner of transportation to use a salt substitute to deice certain highways bordering the Kensico and Croton watershed; prohibits the use of road salt as a deicer on environmentally sensitive highways.

       AN ACT to amend the transportation law, in relation to the use  of  salt
         substitutes

         THE  PEOPLE OF THE STATE OF NEW YORK, REPRESENTED IN SENATE AND ASSEM-
       BLY, DO ENACT AS FOLLOWS:

    1    Section 1. The transportation law is amended by adding a  new  section
    2  14-n to read as follows:
    3    S  14-N.  SALT SUBSTITUTE. 1. THE COMMISSIONER, UPON CONSULTATION WITH
    4  THE COMMISSIONER OF ENVIRONMENTAL CONSERVATION AND  THE  NEW  YORK  CITY
    5  DEPARTMENT   OF  ENVIRONMENTAL  PROTECTION,  IS  HEREBY  AUTHORIZED  AND
    6  DIRECTED TO IDENTIFY THOSE SECTIONS OF  ROADWAYS  LOCATED  EAST  OF  THE
    7  HUDSON  RIVER  WITHIN  THE  KENSICO  AND  CROTON  BASIN  SYSTEMS  OF THE
    8  WATERSHED FOR THE NEW YORK CITY DRINKING WATER SUPPLY  THAT  ARE  WITHIN
    9  ONE THOUSAND FEET OR LESS OF THE PERIMETERS OF THE FOLLOWING RESERVOIRS:
   10  KENSICO,  CROTON,  MUSCOOT, CROSS RIVER, AMAWALK, TITICUS, CROTON FALLS,
   11  DIVERTING, EAST BRANCH, BOG BROOK, MIDDLE BRANCH, EAST BRANCH, AND  BOYD
   12  CORNER.  SUCH  ROADWAYS SHALL BE DEEMED TO BE ENVIRONMENTALLY SENSITIVE.
   13  THE USE OF ROAD SALT AS A DEICER SHALL BE PROHIBITED ON  ENVIRONMENTALLY
   14  SENSITIVE ROADWAYS.
   15    2.  THE  COMMISSIONER IS HEREBY AUTHORIZED TO USE POTASSIUM ACETATE AS
   16  AN ENVIRONMENTALLY BENIGN SUBSTITUTE FOR ROAD  SALT  TO  DEICE  ROADWAYS
   17  DESIGNATED  AS ENVIRONMENTALLY SENSITIVE. THE COMMISSIONER IS AUTHORIZED
   18  TO DESIGN AND EVALUATE  APPLICATION  PROCEDURES  AND  TO  SUPERVISE  THE
   19  APPLICATION  OF POTASSIUM ACETATE SO AS TO MAXIMIZE THE PRODUCT'S EFFEC-
   20  TIVENESS AS A DEICER. IF THE COMMISSIONER DETERMINES THAT THE ONE  THOU-
   21  SAND  FOOT  DISTANCE DOES NOT ACCOUNT FOR ALL THE SIGNIFICANT SOURCES OF
   22  ROAD SALT RUNOFF INTO THE RESERVOIR, THEN  THE  AREA  DESIGNATED  AS  AN
   23  ENVIRONMENTALLY  SENSITIVE  ROADWAY  MAY BE ADJUSTED TO REDUCE ROAD SALT
   24  RUNOFF.
   25    S 2. This act shall take effect on the ninetieth day  after  it  shall
   26  have become a law.

memo:
BILL NUMBER:S2020

TITLE OF BILL:
An act
to amend the transportation law, in relation to the use of salt
substitutes

PURPOSE:
To prevent road salt from degrading the drinking water
reservoirs located in the New York City Watershed in the area east of
the Hudson River because this area is the most susceptible to storm
water runoff from nearby road salt activities.

SUMMARY OF PROVISIONS:
This bill would: (1) authorize the Commissioner
of the NYS Department of Transportation to identify roadways built
within 1/4 mile of the perimeters of New York City drinking water
reservoirs located east of the Hudson River; (2) designate such roads
as "environmentally sensitive" and prohibit the application of road
salt to de-ice environmentally sensitive roadways; and (3) authorize
the Commissioner to use potassium acetate to de-ice environmentally
sensitive roadways and to readjust the 1/4 mile limit if that area is
not sufficient to address the significant sources of road salt runoff.

EXISTING LAW:
The use of road salt to de-ice roadways located in close
proximity to drinking water reservoirs is permitted.

JUSTIFICATION:
Degradation due to pollutants that runoff from the
highway is a serious problem for most of New York City's water supply
because there are many roads in the Kensico and Croton basins that
are located in close proximity to the reservoirs situated therein.
One avoidable pollutant is road salt. Road salt pollutes nearby
drinking water reservoirs when it is released during snow melts.
While its use is important for safe highway transportation
management, there is an environmentally benign alternative potassium
acetate. It is more costly than road salt, but if used judiciously in
only the areas in closest proximity to the most threatened
reservoirs, its cost would be offset by the avoidance of costs to
remediate impaired drinking water supplies. According to the US
Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), potassium acetate is nontoxic
to aquatic habitat and humans; and it was approved by the Federal
Aviation
Administration as effective for runway de-icing operations. Moreover
potassium acetate contains no chlorides so it is non-corrosive. It is
safer for structural steel and reinforcing steel embedded in concrete
and readily biodegrades with little environmental impact. It is
currently used by the National Park Service for use on icy mountain
roads in Yosemite National park. The EPA considers the use of
potassium acetate as an important tool in reducing environmental

impacts associated with storm water run-off. Annual salt use in the
U.S. is approaching 12 million tons with New York reporting the
third highest application rate in the nation with 16.6 tons/lane mile
on average, ranking just below Massachusetts and Vermont. A USGS
report (March 2000) found that the annual road salt application rates
in the Croton watershed basin were (in tons per mile of roadway): 37
on two-lane town, county and state roads; 75 on the Taconic parkway,
and 298 in Interstate 84. These rates are some of the highest in the
nation. The report also found a stable linear correlation between
reservoirs (the focus of the study was to measure groundwater
contamination). As development pressures escalate around the Croton
watershed reservoirs, the pressure to keep
the roads salted during icy and snowy days will also increase.
Rough cost estimates for road salting are $30/ton for the salt and
roughly KS/ton for all associated storage and application costs.
Approximately $10 million/year is spent nationally to mitigate salt
impacts on drinking water, mostly in the Northeast and Midwest
states. This amount does not include costs associated with damage to
roadside vegetation, bridges and vehicles. For each application of
salt, the product alone costs about $4 per lane mile or $8 per mile
per two lane road. In comparison, potassium acetate is sold in
gallons and costs about $3.30 per gallon when purchased in bulk. It
costs about $175 per lane mile for each application. Clearly the
product must be used judiciously and only in areas most threatening
to drinking water supplies.

LEGISLATIVE HISTORY:

2010 - S.2255/A.347 Referred to Transportation
2007 - Referred to Transportation
2006 - Referred to Transportation

FISCAL IMPLICATIONS:
To be determined.

EFFECTIVE DATE:
This act shall take effect on the ninetieth day after
it shall have become law.
